subject_prompt_600:
Arnaud Denjoy
Baire's friend and colleague, Dr. Jean Pierre Brouardel was an authority on Renaissance Renaissance France, and was the author of the monumental work The French Renaissance: A History from the Earliest Times to the Reign of Charles V (1698). His book would have been extremely useful in researching Arnaud Denjoy. It is still one of the most accessible and well-researched books on this subject. The book begins by describing the social and political environment of the period, and then goes on to describe the cultural movements that were taking place. The author shows how these changes affected the language and literature used, and how they reflected the state of society. He argues that it was important for authors to portray the Renaissance as something quite different than what it actually was. For example, his discussion on the rise of the Enlightenment focuses on the works of Descartes, a man who rejected all of the ideas of Aristotle; Brouardel suggests that Descartes' philosophy had nothing to do with the Enlightenment of the 17th century, but had its origins during the late Renaissance when writers started thinking and writing more freely. Brouardel also shows how writers like Diderot and Rousseau came from very different cultural backgrounds, and their works reflect the conflicts between those cultures.
coupled_prompt_600:
René-Louis Baire (1885 - 1965) was a French philosopher and mathematician who is best known for his work on set theory. He has been posthumously awarded several prestigious prizes. Baire is best known as the discoverer of Fermat's Last Theorem and the "Brouwer Theorem". In the mid 19th century, Baire began a lifelong investigation into how human beings relate to mathematics. While his main interest is set theory, he also wrote a number of works on other subjects. 
It is worth noting that this is not to make light of the atrocities committed against the Jews during World War II. Baire was a staunch Zionist, even founding the "Zionist Society in France". Nevertheless, his research suggests that the vast majority of French people were well-intentioned, rational people who, in some cases, could be deceived by those claiming to be motivated purely by compassion. It seems to me that we have made too many mistakes in our moral development in recent history. For instance, the Nazis used propaganda of the highest order to convince Germans that all Jews were evil. We must be careful, however, before we believe that all Muslims are equally bad. This is not always the case. Even when it seems like it, there are many different religions with very different values. I think we can all agree that one can sympathize with people who speak French to us, or who attend our concerts or enjoy French cuisine, regardless of the fact that they do not worship at the same churches or mosques as we do.
What Baire is doing is extremely important in our culture. It shows that there can be a way forward to reconcile our individualistic views with universalistic ones. A true and open society requires people to listen, respect others, respect their individuality, and be responsible for themselves in their personal lives. I think it is critical that we learn how to live in such societies and not let their existence be undermined through racism, xenophobia, and other forms of bigotry. It doesn't matter if your arguments are rooted in science, history, philosophy, logic, morality, etc. As long as you acknowledge your own biases, I'm sure your reasoning will be valid.
I understand, of course, that many people would say that this essay is simply another attack on Islam. I take my hat off to anyone who truly has a desire to destroy the ideology of Islam, which is nothing short of a religion that has killed millions in its attempt to dominate the world. If we want to know how to deal with this threat, we need to get beyond the tribalism and hatred. We must recognize that this ideology has inspired countless terrorists. We must recognize that the ideologies behind al-Qaeda, ISIS, and similar groups are nothing more than religious fanatics who seek to create their own state based upon intolerance and ignorance.
